content.raw:
We noticed those, but it's very unclear from the printout where the warnings are originating, since the console output just points you to a macro in a system header.

Someone will need to boot up Windows and dig into it to figure out what lines are actually emitting the warnings.

update.description:
This is a retargeted version of pull request #249. This PR is aimed at the default branch instead of a prototyping branch. It also contains some changes based on reviewer feedback.

Two things still on the todo list:

1. Write more tests for the raw publications and subscriptions. It would be especially good to have tests that use multiple processes. Two sub-tests were added in 1cc9ddf but more are needed.

2. Determine whether we would rather have the `Publish(~)` implementation proposed [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/pull-requests/249/wip-subscribe-and-publish-raw-serialized/activity#comment-51885932) which is cleaner and easier to follow, or the current implementation which is more aggressive about avoiding unnecessary deserialization.

Note that some of the reviewer feedback is being addressed separately in pull request #250, and I expect that branch to get merged first.
update.title: Subscribe and publish raw (serialized) data

content.raw: This file will go away when we update to the latest 'doc' pattern. These changes won't affect the release either.
content.html: This file will go away when we update to the latest 'doc' pattern. These changes won't affect the release either.

content.raw: Exactly.
content.html: Exactly.

content.raw: You mean to use `google::protobuf::Message` in `Advertise()`, and then, use the specific  type in `RawPublish()` (`ignition::msgs::StringMsg` for example)?
content.html: You mean to use google::protobuf::Message in Advertise(), and then, use the specific type in RawPublish() (ignition::msgs::StringMsg for example)?

content.raw: Also note that if `_msgType` doesn't match the message type that it advertised itself as, the `PublishRaw` function will return false and not publish the message (unless it was originally advertised as a generic publisher, in which case it returns true and allows the message through). This gives us an (albeit small) extra layer of confidence that the person requesting the publication knows what they're doing.
content.html: Also note that if _msgType doesn't match the message type that it advertised itself as, the PublishRaw function will return false and not publish the message (unless it was originally advertised as a generic publisher, in which case it returns true and allows the message through). This gives us an (albeit small) extra layer of confidence that the person requesting the publication knows what they're doing.

content.raw:
Sorry for not catching this comment.

The message type won't be known if it advertised itself as a generic Protobuf message type. We use the generic message type as a catch-all for advertising and subscribing.
content.html:
Sorry for not catching this comment.

The message type won't be known if it advertised itself as a generic Protobuf message type. We use the generic message type as a catch-all for advertising and subscribing.

content.html: I'm removing my approval to give @caguero a chance to look this over again.

content.html: @caguero : Can you offer an alternative approach?

content.raw:
Conflicts should be resolved 7b4933d

One possible concern is that local raw subscribers are still single-threaded, even though the local ordinary subscribers are using the `WorkerPool` to multithread.

We could make the raw subscriptions multi-threaded, we would just need to make a copy of the serialized data `msgBuffer` into a `std::shared_ptr` to ensure that the data is safe for multithreading.
content.html:
Conflicts should be resolved 7b4933d

One possible concern is that local raw subscribers are still single-threaded, even though the local ordinary subscribers are using the WorkerPool to multithread.

We could make the raw subscriptions multi-threaded, we would just need to make a copy of the serialized data msgBuffer into a std::shared_ptr to ensure that the data is safe for multithreading.
